title: Car tax rules are changing on Saturday – here’s what you need to know
text:
Car dealers are expected to be rammed with customers this week (Picture: Getty) Car dealers are expected to be rammed with customers this week looking to buy a new vehicle before car tax changes mean it could cost hundreds if not thousands more. 
New tax rules which will come in place from April 1 will significantly increase the amount buyers have to pay on certain models due to a change in emissions bands for new cars.
Children are 'getting high by sniffing burning wheelie bins' If you car is already registered then the good news is that current road tax bands won’t change but if you’re looking to buy a new one then it’s worth doing it sooner rather than later.
The changes were brought in by former chancellor George Osborne to reflect the fact most new cars have such low emissions that they end up paying no tax – costing the treasury millions.
Here’s what you need to know.
What will be different? The changes reflect the number of low emission new vehicles made since 2001 (Picture: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg via Getty Images) If a car is registered after April 1 it will pay a one-off tax charge for the first year that varies depending on the CO2 emissions of the vehicle – measured in g/km.
From the second year onwards all vehicles will pay a flat rate of £140 with the only exemption for vehicles that have zero emissions – electric.
The most significant change will be seen in the one-off first year payment which will jump dramatically. for higher emission vehicles.
Where as the standard rate will fall beyond the first year in some models.
Cars worth more than £40,000 will also pay an annual supplement of £310 between years two and six.
(Picture: Gov.uk) As detailed by Auto Express , that differs significantly from the current first year rate set out below.
The current emissions bands that will change for new vehicles from April 1 (Picture: Metro.co.uk) For more information visit the DVLA .
By comparison, this means a car emitting 151g/km will be charged £500 instead of £180.
Those emitting 171g/km will be charged £800 instead of £295.
What does this mean for you? Buying befofe the system kicks in could save you a vast amount of money (Picture: Getty) James Hind, founder of carwow.co.uk said previously: ‘Some models will cost significantly more to tax each year, so there are long-term savings to be had by buying before the new system kicks in.
‘Hybrid cars and small petrol-powered city cars will be cheaper to tax if you buy before April 1.’
